aims.title: Safety
aims.text: Highlight the vulnerability of cyclists to motorists who appear blind to our presence

aims.title: Environment
aims.text: Protest against transport powered by non sustainable forms of energy

aims.title: Body Positivity
aims.text: Healthy body and healthy mind by fitness and exercise

facts.title: Facts about cylist safety in Australia
facts.intro: In 2017, the Bike Network released a report about cyclist safety and collisions from 2012 and 2016. These are some of the more intresting facts
facts.source: Report is related to data collected within 2012-2016 in Australia by Bicycle Network

list.fact: Crashes are most common during peak hour but the number of crashes in the morning almost double the afternoon numbers. So make sure you get your coffee hit first before you start your morning commute to stay alert!
The majority of crashes actually happen when you least expect it. Bicycle Network worked out that 81.4% of crashes happen when the weather is fine and 70.7% when the road is flat.

People tend to ride more in the summer months so it's no surprise that crashes reduce during the colder months but then increase in Spring with October (only in Straya) being the month with the most crashes.

It is well known that intersections pose a high risk for people who ride bikes. Therefore it is no surprise that intersections remain the highest risk area with 42.8% of crashes. Make sure you stop at red lights and watch out for those trams Melburnians!
Only 20.9% of crashes occur in environments where there are no vehicles highlighting the importance of separation.

13.8% of the crashes happened at low speed where the rider was going less than 11km/h and almost half of crashes (46.1%) occurred where the rider was travelling less than 21km/h. The exception being if you are prone to attempting crazy stunts on Melbourne Bicycles.

It's not all bad news, the chances of actually having a crash is extremely small. Less than 1% cyclists crash each year and from this only 0.001% end up in hospital on any given day. We still recommend keeping a spare first aid kit in your bike bag at all times just in case!
Nearly half of crashes are reported to the police (47.6%) and when a report occurs 24.4% describe the experience as negative.
